utterances: Some of the directors held out, you know.
They didn't want our generation to come in and, if you will, taint their product.
Well, nevertheless, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valence, boy, if you've never seen that movie, John Wayne, Woody Strode, Jimmy Stewart, terrific movie.
Go rent it tonight.
It's, and Lee Marvin, of course, is Liberty Valence himself, one of the truly evil roles ever, of all time.
But Gene Pitney, I did read that he was the first pop star to sing at the Oscars.
Exactly.
In 1962, he was there and, very, very nervous.

Gene told me in one of our interviews how nervous he was to be up there in front of Bob Hope, who was hosting the show, and all the glitterati of Hollywood, including Marilyn Monroe in the audience that night.

And he had to walk down the stairs on the set, I guess from singing his song to heading off towards Bob Hope, and he was so afraid he was going to fall down the stairs and look like an absolute clown.
But fortunately Gene did great.
And he was the first rock and roll performer ever to be featured in an Oscars telecast.
Now he was, in later years, still very popular.
In Europe, toured frequently as, if you are joining us late, he died in Cardiff, in Whales in his hotel room earlier today.
Or I guess after a concert last night.
What was his appeal there, do you think?
Well Gene, besides having tremendous appeal to the British rock and roll fans, where he toured at least a month every year.
Much more so, in fact, in the last half-dozen years Gene appeared far more frequently in the UK than he did in the U.S.
But he also sang in a number of foreign languages.
He was very popular in Italy for many years.
In fact he sang a number of songs in Italian at the prestigious Sanremo Music Festival.
So Gene was as comfortable in a number of different languages.
That helped to maintain his appeal in Europe.
And of course, come 1990, Gene had the only number one record of his career in the UK, singing Something's Got a Hold of My Heart along with British vocalist Marc Almond.
That was in 1990, twenty-five years after he basically fell off the American charts.
Mike McCann, thanks very much for being with us today.
We appreciate your time.
Thank you, Neal.
Mike McCann, a music journalist and rock and roll historian.
He joined us from the studios of member station WSHU in Fairfield, Connecticut.
We'll leave you with one of Gene Pitney's favorite songs, If I Didn't Have a Dime.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
(Soundbite of Gene Pitney's If I Didn't Have a Dime)
Getting a rise out of these geese is a challenge.
They're city dwellers, rounded up in a Cleveland park.
Like many of the birds near airports, they're well acclimated to human activity, and that's part of the problem.
They're obviously not afraid of this aircraft.
It's a nine-foot wing span that's coming right at them.
They even challenge it in some cases.
Then there is the ducking response, but they're definitely not taking initiative to get out of the way.
So what might warn the birds off?
Qantas Airlines recently reported a reduction in bird strikes when it mounted pulsing lights on 737s.
Blackwell's team wants to firm up the science behind those observations.
In this experiment, we run a treatment with the aircraft approaching without lights and one with the lights.
You want to know if the lights make a difference.
I want to know if the lights can make a difference, even if they give us a slight edge, and then can we tweak the system a little bit more?
Can we start playing with wavelengths that these birds can see better?
Biologist Esteban Fernandez-Juricic looks at video from a previous day's flights in a nearby trailer.
The first reaction that you see is that the birds pull together, and they group together very quickly as the airplane goes by.
And then the second reaction that we can see here is that some individuals duck down right there.
The geese are ducking.
They seem to regard the plane as a predator.
The challenge is to make that predator as threatening as possible.
But first, Fernandez needs to understand what the birds actually see.
Humans have three visual pigments, birds have four visual pigments, and this visual pigment usually is in the UV range, in the ultraviolet range.
So birds can perceive more colors than humans can.
So we might end up some day with lights on aircraft that are ultraviolet that we can't see that the birds can.
We might.
For now, though, the secret of a finely tuned aerial warning system remains with the birds.
(Soundbite of goose honking)
Robert Benincasa, NPR News.
And after four years of chaos end violence in Iraq, nearly two million Iraqis remain outside their country.
That's according to the U.N.
agency for refugees.
Most of the Iraqis who have fled are overwhelming neighboring states - Jordan and Syria in particular.
In Europe though, Iraqi applications for asylum have doubled over the past three years.
Few European countries are offering much refuge with one exception.
NPR's Emily Harris reports.
It's recess at Rosenberg School in Sodertalje, a town about an hour south of Stockholm, Sweden.
A handful of young girls are spending the break singing.
(Soundbite of children singing foreign language)
They're all from Iraq, Baghdad, Mosul, Basra.
None of them have been here for more than a year and they have a lot of company.
In 2006, almost 9,000 Iraqis applied for asylum in Sweden.
It was triple what the country was expecting and more than 40 percent of all Iraqi refugee claims in Europe.
No, nay(ph) in the Iraq, and if you go, no, no.
Fifty-year-old Laura arrived in Sweden three months ago.
She paid a smuggler about $30,000 to get her and two daughters here.
Laura is afraid to use her real name because her husband and two other children are still trying to leave Iraq.
The turning point for Laura was when her son was kidnapped.
(Through translator) That was the day when I decided to leave.
I haven't been thinking about it earlier, but at moment, I just decided.
Her son was released after three days and a $25,000 ransom.
Laura is a Christian and blames Muslims for the chaos in her home country.
But Iraqi Muslims are also seeking refuge in Sweden.
Twenty four-year-old Reisan Abbas is Shia, and was an engineering student in Baghdad.
(Through translator) You could be killed at any moment without reason.
At the university, they can just come into your department and kill you.
Ahlam Hamid Abbas shares the same fears.
It's not about being killed in the university department, but in her home in Baghdad's Amiriyah neighborhood.
She's a middle-aged Sunni woman who smiles and nods when introduced and cries when she talks about Iraq.
(Speaking foreign language)
It's impossible in Iraq, she says.
It's miserable.
Bombs and explosions.
No electricity, no gas.
This never happened before the Americans came, she says, only after.
Killings, bombing, explosions, no security, no economy.
It's not possible to live, she says.
No one knows what to do.
Her relatives ignore her outbursts as if they know it by heart.
They keep sipping tea and serving cake in the small living room in a row house north of Stockholm.
Like many recent arrivals, Abbas and her 88-year-old mother came to Sweden because other close family members already live here.
Tens of thousands of Iraqis sought refuge in Sweden during Saddam Hussein's rule.
But Sweden also handles Iraqi asylum claims differently than other European countries.
I will say that about 90 percent of the Iraqis are staying at this time.

Fredrik Beijer, director of Sweden's asylum processing, says even Iraqis with weak claims of individual persecution, now often get residence permits with full rights to work and welfare for a practical reason - Sweden won't send them back, figures they'll be here for a while and would rather try to integrate them.

When you see that you are not being able to send back this person in a foreseeable time, you can say that they are going to get connected to Sweden if you can say that, really from the beginning, then you have the possibility to stay.
Doesn't everybody die at the end of the first one?
I am not criminal.
I am immigrant from Poland and I want to be legal here in this country.

In the case of the United States versus Zacarias Moussaoui, as to Count One, conspiracy to commit acts of terrorism transcending national boundaries, and Count Three, conspiracy to destroy aircraft, and Count Four, conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction, the jury has found that the defendant should be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of release.
